body.p:
SQL Logging implements Adium logging into a PostgreSQL database.
This offers several advantages:

ul.li: Very easy to view logs between certain time periods.

body.p: To install this, a few things are required. Setup, however, is not that bad. At the base level, all that is required is PostgreSQL (duh). It can be installed from source, via fink, or by a package.

I would recommend a package by Mark Liyanage.
You can find information and installation instructions at http://www.entropy.ch/software/macosx/postgresql/.

There is also a set of installation instructions for installing PostgreSQL at http://developer.apple.com/internet/macosx/postgres.html. That tutorial is very good. It covers installing PostgreSQL from source, shows how to use PostgreSQL with Perl (necessary for parser.pl or parser-2.pl to work), Java (necessary for the JSP viewers to work), and PHP (not necessary for this). It also covers how to administer the database using phpPgAdmin, an administration program with a web interface.
After you have PostgreSQL set up, create a user with your username.
Then create a database with your username:

After a database is created, you should be able to connect to it by simply typing psql. To log information, Adium will expect to have a certain setup in the database. Get the following package: adium.tar.gz. After using Stuffit Expander or the command line to unpack it, there should these files inside:
Setup files:
sql/adium.sql (main database setup) [Changes]
sql/tsearch.sql (setup for fast searching) [Changes]
Web Viewing Pages
jsp/index.jsp (main message viewer) [Changes]
jsp/search.jsp (searching tool) [Changes]
jsp/statistics.jsp (user statistics) [Changes]
jsp/images/ (images for the statistics page)
Useful Perl Scripts
parser.pl (script to import Adium logs <= 1.6.x) [Changes]
parser-2.pl (script to import logs >= 2.0) [Changes]
restore.pl (returns original log files to pristine state) [Changes]
These HTML/XML pages:
index (this page) [HTML Changes] [XML Changes]
resin (JSP setup instructions) [HTML Changes] [XML Changes]
tsearch (tsearch setup instructions) [HTML Changes] [XML Changes]
technical (technical details/detailed parser instructions) [HTML Changes] [XML Changes]
adium.xslt (XSLT stylesheet to transform XML to HTML) [Changes]
The JSP files will allow you to view IMs with a web interface. These can be used locally and from the world-wide web.

The SQL files are a language that tells the database what type of information to store and tables to create. They are split into two files: the file called "adium.sql" will create the default table layout. tsearch.sql will enable it to use a module called "tsearch", which allows for very, very fast searching. It requires slightly more setup, which is why it has been split into a different file.

To create the table needed for message logging, open a terminal window and switch to the directory that contains the files you just downloaded. (If you don't know how to do that, I would suggest this series of articles). Type psql < adium.sql. You should get messages like TABLE CREATED. To ensure that it worked, type psql. Then you will be connected to the database. You should see something like this:

div.pre:
Welcome to psql 7.3, the PostgreSQL interactive terminal.
Type: \copyright for distribution terms \h for help with SQL commands \? for help on internal slash commands \g or terminate with semicolon to execute query \q to quit
jmelloy=#

body.p: To see the table you just created, you need to alter your search path.

After typing that, you should see the confirmation message ALTER USER. That changes only new instances of your user, so either quit psql (\q) and start again, or type set search_path=adium,public;. After doing either of those, type "\d" and you should see something like this:

div.pre: jmelloy=# \d List of relations Schema | Name | Type | Owner ------------------+------------------------------+----------+--------- adium | messages | table | jmelloy adium | messages_message_id_seq | sequence | jmelloy adium | users | table | jmelloy adium | users_user_id_seq | sequence | jmelloy adium | message_v | view | jmelloy (5 rows)

body.p: The users table is very simple, a column for screenname, and an id. The messages table stores all the messages themselves, and a reference to the users table. Message_v contains a combination of both: the message, and the screenname who sent it, instead of a number.

At this point, you're ready to use the plugin. You can run parser.pl to insert all of your old logs into the database. To run the script, a few modules are needed for your perl installation. The first one is called "DBI" (DataBase Interface) and the second "DBD-PG" (DataBase Driver-PostgreSQL). Both can be gotten from fink or CPAN. The fink modules are called dbi-pm and dbd-pg-pm (in unstable). More information on installation and use can be found in Technical Details. Run it by typing ./parser.pl. It should automatically find all of your logs, but you may need to edit the paths. As it stands, it will run over every screenname who logged into your computer. In future versions, it will be able to specify a specific user.

Download the newest source of Adium 2.0 from CVS, and compile it. Instructions for downloading through anonymous CVS access can be found here. To compile, open "Adium.pbproj" and hit the "Build" button in the top left. Switch the target to "SQL Logger" (it should start at "Adium") and hit "Build". Locate the built application, and control-click it. Go to "Show Package Contents" navigate to the Plugin folder, and add "SQL Logger.AdiumPlugin" to it. That should be all it takes to install it.

You can also download a compiled plugin here: sql-logger.tar.gz, uncompress it, and drop it in the Adium application as discussed above. This will not work without PostgreSQL installed on your system, and the proper database setup.

Currently, the plugin doesn't have any prefs. If your databae setup is non-standard, you need to set an environmental variable (PGHOST, PGUSER, etc) as described in the PostgreSQL docs. If the plugin is installed correctly, it works very unobtrusively. It never does anything unless there is a problem, so if you start it up and don't get an "Unable to Connect to Database" dialog, it's probably working.
To check that either parser.pl worked correctly, and/or it's correctly logging, type psql. To view messages:

div.pre: select * from adium.message_v order by message_date desc limit 5;

body.p: You should see the last five messages you sent/received. To search for messages, you can do

div.pre: select * from adium.message_v where message ~ 'search string';

body.p: This interface is kind of a pain, and searching can be made faster.

To make searching faster, it is best to install the tsearch module. To make the interface suck less, I've written a web-interface in JSP. It uses a JSP engine (Resin or Tomcat). I use Resin. Instructions are in the sidebar on the left.
